DOC.brief_summary: Slow axonal Kv7 potassium channels are found along unmyelinated axons and at the nodes of Ranvier of myelinated axons in peripheral nerve. As such the pharmacological activation of Kv7 channels offers a potential means of reducing the excitability of peripheral axons. To determine whether this is the case for human peripheral myelinated axons, the effect of the Kv7 channel agonist flupirtine on the electrical excitability of A fibres was examined in both isolated segments of human sural nerve in vitro and in motor axons of the median nerve supplying abductor pollicus brevis in vivo. Axonal excitability was assessed in 21 human sural nerve fascicles in vitro and in 20 volunteers in vivo using threshold tracking in QTRAC (Â© Institute of Neurology, London, UK). Strength-duration time constant, rheobase current, relative refractory period (RRP), post spike superexcitability at 5 and 7 ms and threshold electrotonus over the 90 100 ms period were used as indices of electrical excitability. In addition, suppression of ectopic discharge in a model of upper limb ischaemia.
DOC.brief_title: Effect of the Kv7-channel Opener Flupirtine on the Excitability of Human Peripheral Myelinated Axons in Vivo
